caption: This statue in Paris, the town where Simon Bolivar stayed for some time in his youth, was a gift by the Bolivarian republics to Paris in 1930. It is an exact copy of the statue in Bogota (1910) made by French sculptor Emmanuel Fr√©miet famous for his equestrian statue of Jeanne d‚ÄôArc in Paris.

The Equestrian Statue of Sim√≥n Bol√≠var, also known as the Monument √† Simon Bolivar, is a prominent monument located in Paris, France. It is dedicated to Sim√≥n Bol√≠var, a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a key role in Latin America's struggle for independence from Spanish colonial rule.  The monument was designed by the French sculptor Aim√©-Jules Dalou and was inaugurated in 1902. It is situated in the Parc de l'Am√©rique-Latine, in the 7th arrondissement of Paris.  The statue depicts Sim√≥n Bol√≠var on horseback, with one arm raised in a gesture of leadership and determination. Bol√≠var is portrayed in his military attire, symbolizing his role as a revolutionary leader. The monument is made of bronze and stands on a granite pedestal.  The Monument √† Simon Bolivar serves as a tribute to Bol√≠var's significant contributions to the fight for independence and his vision of a united Latin America. It represents his ideals of freedom, justice, and the rights of the people.  Visiting the monument offers a chance to learn more about Sim√≥n Bol√≠var's legacy and his impact on the history of Latin America. It is a symbol of unity and inspiration for those who strive for independence, equality, and progress in the region.

Sim√≥n Jos√© Antonio de la Sant√≠sima Trinidad Bol√≠var y Palacios de Aguirre, Ponte-Andrade y Blanco, known simply as Sim√≥n Bol√≠var (Caracas, 24 July 1783 ‚Äì Santa Marta, 17 December 1830), was a Venezuelan general, patriot and revolutionary; he was awarded the honorary title of Libertador (Liberator) due to his decisive contribution to the independence of Bolivia, Colombia, Peru and Venezuela. He was also president of the Republics of Colombia, Venezuela, Bolivia and Peru. He is considered, together with Jos√© de San Mart√≠n, one of the most representative figures in the history of Latin America. Founder and president of Bolivia and Greater Colombia, a nation that sought to establish itself as a political-military confederation in Latin America, Bol√≠var was considered for his actions and ideas as El hombre de Am√©rica ("The Man of America" ), and one of the most important figures in the political and cultural history of Latin American countries, in most of which he is considered a hero. He has received recognition in various parts of the world, with statues, monuments, parks, squares and streets dedicated to him. Furthermore, his ideas and political-social ideals led to the birth of a current called Bolivarianism.

What a pleasant surprise in this beautiful city. A wonderful statue of such an important character for all Latin Americans, the liberator Sim√≥n Bolivar. I can't describe the emotion you feel, I can only assure you that I felt for a moment that I was back in my beloved Venezuela.

I was surprised to meet our liberator by chance, I didn't know that in Paris there was an equestrian statue in honor of him, however it was a pleasant surprise, a full-scale statue, very beautiful and very well preserved, much better than any other statue of Simon Bol√≠var in Venezuela.

The monument is a bronze equestrian statue depicting Simon Bolivar (1783-1830), on horseback. Statue is placed on a pedestal. Located on the Cours de la Reine in Paris, near the Pont Alexandre-III. Fourth copy of the work of French sculptor Emmanuel Fr√©miet, commissioned at the beginning of the 20th century by the city of Bogata (Colombia). Copy offered in 1930 by the Republics of Latin America during the centenary of the death of Simon Bolivar. Two other copies were erected in Barranquilla (Colombia) and La Paz (Bolivia). Originally installed at Place de la Porte de Champerret, the statue was moved to Cours de la Reine in 1980.
